revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1603|music}}
The year '''1603 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == *[[Orlando Gibbons]] becomes a member of the [[Chapel Royal]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Palisca |first= Claude V. |title=Baroque Music |origyear=1968 |edition=3rd |series=Prentice Hall History of Music |year=1991 |publisher=[[Prentice Hall]] |location=[[Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey|Englewood Cliffs]] |isbn=0-13-058496-7 |page=301 }}</ref> *[[Giovanni Artusi]] attacks the "crudities" and "licence" in the works of [[Claudio Monteverdi]]. *[[Sebastian Aguilera de Heredia]] leaves his post as organist of [[Huesca]] Cathedral to become maestro de música at [[La Seo Cathedral]] in Saragossa.
== Publications == *[[Carlo Gesualdo]] – ''Sacrarum cantionum liber primus'', 2 vols. (Naples: Costantino Vitale) *[[Ascanio Mayone]] – ''Il Primo libro di diversi capricci per sonare'', keyboard music *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – ''Il quatro libro de madrigali a cinque voci di Claudio Monteverdi Maestro della Musica del Ser.mo Sig.r Duca di Mantova'' (fourth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5), published in [[Venice]]
== Classical music == *[[Tomás Luis de Victoria]] – ''[[Officium Defunctorum (Victoria)|Officium Defunctorum]]'', composed for the funeral obsequies of [[Maria of Austria, Holy Roman Empress]], performed on April 22 and 23
== Opera == *''none listed''
== Births == *[[March 18]] – King [[John IV of Portugal]], composer, patron of music and the arts, and writer on music (died 1656) *November – [[Francesco Foggia]], composer (died 1688) *''date unknown'' **[[Denis Gaultier]], French lutenist and composer (died 1672) **[[William Smith (composer)|William Smith]], liturgical composer (died 1645) *''probable'' – [[Benedetto Ferrari]], composer and theorbo player (died 1681)
== Deaths == *June – [[Baldassare Donato]], composer and singer (born 1525-1530) *[[July 4]] – [[Philippe de Monte]], Flemish composer (born 1521) *[[August 2]] – [[Rinaldo dall'Arpa]], composer, singer and harpist *[[August 16]] – Cardinal [[Silvio Antoniani]], amateur musician (born 1540) *[[September 25]] – [[Stefano Felis]], Neapolitan composer and music teacher (born c.1538) *[[October 23]] – [[Johann Wanning]], Dutch-born composer, kapellmeister and alto singer (born 1537) *''date unknown'' – [[Ambrosio Cotes]], Spanish composer (born c.1550)
== References == <references/>
[[Category:1603|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{ Infobox musical artist | name = Against All Authority | image = | caption = Against All Authority Logo | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Cutler Ridge]], [[Florida]], [[United States]] | genre = [[Punk rock]], [[Ska punk]], [[Hardcore punk]], [[Anarcho-punk]] | years_active = 1992-2007 | label = [[Hopeless Records|Hopeless]] Far Out Records | associated_acts = Nobodys Hero | website = | current_members = Danny Lore
Joe Koontz | past_members = Spikey Goldbach
Jeremy Kaiser
[[Fin Leavell]]
Kris King
Macbeth Proenza
Tim Pagones
Tim Coats
Joey Jewkes
Jason Lederman
Alan V.
Sid
Marcio }} '''Against All Authority''' (often abbreviated '''-AAA-''') was an American [[punk band]], formed in Florida in 1992. Playing in the [[ska punk]] style,{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/Music/Against_All_Authority/Discography/album/P279226/R832130/ |title=Restoration of Chaos & Order Album Review, Songs, Ratings |work=Starpulse.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-11}} their business practice follows a stringent [[DIY ethic]]. Since their disbandment, Joe has started [[ajamrecords.com|A Jam Records]] with friend Dave Santos. They have been signing local punk and alternative acts in Florida, most recently Pop Punk band [http://dialdrivefl.com Dial Drive ] from [[Orlando, Florida]] ==History== Against All Authority was founded in [[Cutler Ridge, Florida]] in [[1992 in music|1992]],{{cite web | title=Against All Authority|work=Allmusic| url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p279226|pure_url=yes}}| accessdate=June 11, 2007 }} driven by willingness to promote their message—"questioning our economic differences and promoting our human similarities", as stated by their now defunct official website. A strong engagement in political and social issues is clearly evident in their lyrics. The band maintain a fierce DIY stance influenced by the approach of the [[Dead Kennedys]] and [[Subhumans (UK band)|Subhumans]].{{cite web |title=A Punk Band That Most Certainly Does Not Suck |work=[[Nerve (magazine)|Nerve Magazine]] |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928192630/http://www.thenervemagazine.com/2006/07/article_template.php?id=1 |url=http://www.thenervemagazine.com/2006/07/article_template.php?id=1 |accessdate=June 11, 2007}} Early in their career the band decided to book concerts, make recordings and even produce band T-shirts on their own. Their first release "Above The Law" was released on Far Out Records. Later they signed on independent label [[Hopeless Records]], becoming one of their major bands. In addition to touring and recording, the band is frequently involved in demonstrations and social projects. They have also influenced a number of other bands. Guitar player Joe Koontz has formed a new band called Nobody's Hero, with members of [[The Vandals]] and [[Guajiro (band)|Guajiro]]. Trombonist [[Fin Leavell]] is now fronting the band [[Nightswim]]. Drummer Macbeth Proenza also formed a new band called Hit Play!, with former members of Polly Esther, Underpaid, Crooked Edge & Hero of Our time . == Members == * Danny Lore – Bass and Vocals * Joe Koontz – Guitar and Backing Vocals * Joey Jewkes - Trumpet * [[Fin Leavell|Allan 'Fin' Leavell]] – Bass Trombone * Craig Malzacher - Trumpet * Spikey Goldbach – Drums * Jeremy Kaiser – Trumpet * Tim "FarOut" Pagones - Trombone * Tim Coats - Alto and Bari Sax * Kris King - Drums * Macbeth Proenza – Drums * Jason Lederman – Drums * Alan Veronese – Trumpet * Marcio "Grim" - Drums * Sid Goldberger - Drums * Millan Aguero - Drums ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== Destroy What Destroys You (1996) * ''[[All Fall Down (Against All Authority album)|All Fall Down]]'' (1998) * ''[[24 Hour Roadside Resistance]]'' (2000) * ''[[Nothing New for Trash Like You]]'' (2001) * ''[[The Restoration of Chaos & Order]]'' (2006) ===Split=== * ''[[Against All Authority / Common Rider]]'' (2005) Close My Eyes" ** "Out A Luck" * ''[[Warped Tour 2002]]'' (2002 SideOneDummy) ** "Mr. International" * ''[[Hopelessly Devoted to You Vol. 5]]'' (2004 Hopeless) ** "Wet Foot Policy" * ''[[Hopelessly [[File:Altavistapeto.jpg|thumb|400px|Petroglyphs at Altavista Site, Compostela, Nayarit.]]
The '''Altavista petroglyph complex''' is located near the village and beach-town of [[Chacala]], south of the Compostela Municipality, in [[Nayarit]] [[Mexico]].
The area is known as "La Pila del Rey", "Chacalán", "El Santuario", "The Petroglyphs” or "the Altavista petroglyphs", near the Jaltemba Bay, in the Pacific Ocean of Nayarit.<ref name= Richard >{{cite journal |last= Lawhorn |first= Richard |date= |title= Petroglyphs at Altavista |trans-title= Petroglifos en Altavista |journal= |location= |url=http://richardlawhorn.com/altavista/pila_del_rey.html |accessdate=Oct 2010}}</ref>
This region was originally home to the largely unstudied [[Tecoxquin]] (Tequectequi) native culture dating from approximately 2000 BC to 2300 BCE.<ref name="Vecinal">{{cite book |title=Pro-conservacion Difusion del Patrimonio Historico Cultural de Las Varas Nayarit A.C. |last= |first= |authorlink= |year= |publisher=Ejido de Altavista. C.E.C.A.N. / I.N.A.H. |location= |isbn= |pages= }}</ref> It contains 56 petroglyphs whose antiquity cannot be accurately determined. Aside from its cultural and archeological importance, the site remains an important religious center for the [[Huichol people|Huichol]]es who still leave offerings and perform ceremonies here.<ref name="MexDes">{{cite journal|last=Armendáriz |first=Lorenzo |date=February 2008 |title=Viva la Riviera Nayarita |journal=Guía México Desconocido |volume=372 |pages=70–77 |url=http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/8261-Viva-la-Riviera-Nayarita.-Sus-playas,-sus-frutos-del-mar,-su-paz |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811110947/http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/notas/8261-Viva-la-Riviera-Nayarita.-Sus-playas%2C-sus-frutos-del-mar%2C-su-paz |archivedate=2014-08-11 }}</ref>
In prehispanic times, the Compostela municipality area was inhabited by the Mazatán peoples, tributary of Xalisco-Zacualpan Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_nayarit COMPOSTELA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517162123/http://www.e-local.gob.mx/wb2/ELOCAL/EMM_nayarit |date=2011-05-17 }} Enciclopedia de los Municipios de México Nayarit (Spanish) Oct. 2010</ref>
==Petroglyphs== The Tecoxquines (Aztec Group) engraved images in volcanic stone over two thousand years ago near Las Piletas. These petroglyphs perhaps were symbolic elements of everyday life, as far as health, fertility, rains, and crops. The rock carvings might have been meant as prayers or offerings to the gods responsible for these things.<ref name=Richard />
There are fifteen signs (Spanish & English posted along entrance path,<ref name=Richard /> a brief summary is provided below:
=== Sign 1 - Altavista=== Altavista petroglyphs archaeological site, located along the sides of a creek on the slopes the Copo volcano. Covers an area of approximately 80 hectares, with a large concentration of petroglyphs. (More than 2000 engravings identified)<ref name=Richard />
=== Sign 2 - The Tecoxquin (Throat-Cutters) === Original Altavista inhabitants. This native group inhabited a vast region covering the South coast of Nayarit, neighbouring coasts, and mountainous regions of Jalisco, Mexico. They were mainly farmers, fishermen, salt producers and traders of cocoa and cotton. The Tecoxquines were organized in a number of villages under the control of Teuzacualpan Chila Valley (modern city of Zacualpan). Business links allowed them to develop an intensive trade, reached Sinaloa to the north and Colima and Michoacán to the South and East.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 3 - Religious Life (Tecoxquines)=== No doubt, many religious ceremonies at this site were based on nahualism. [[Nagual|Nahualism]] or [[Shamanism]] as former religious practices whereby people communicated with their gods and spirits during altered states of consciousness. This tradition has deep roots in the region; the Nayarit word derives from the word "nahualli". The Tecoxquines used psychotropic plants and tobacco plants to achieve states of ecstasy and communicate with their gods.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 4 - The Last of The Tecoxquines=== [[File:Altavistapeto3.jpg|thumb|350px|Petroglyphs at Altavista Site, Compostela, Nayarit.]] After the Spanish conquest, the Tecoxquines completely annihilated by epidemics and forced labor. Today native cities of the region still talk about "white Indians," ghosts appearing from the mountains to honor their ancient gods.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 5 – The Tecuales=== The Tecoxquin ancient villages, as far as the Ixtapa salt producers, were populated by Tecuales, ancestors of the current Huichol.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 6 - The Water Cycle === Nayarit State is characterized by heavy rainfall. Rainfall is concentrated between May and October. The Altavista mountains attract heavy rains leaving drier areas to the East (desert weather at the opposite side). Perhaps because of this abundance of water, Altavista was considered a special place.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 7 - Tomoanchan (or Tamoanchan)=== [[Tamoanchan]] is a mythical paradisiac location known to the [[Mesoamerican]] cultures of the central Mexican region in the Late Postclassical period, is a central part of the ancient Mesoamerican cosmology. Tamoanchan is the cosmic tree that connects life and supports the world. Its roots are underground in the water and fertility field. Its trunk is between human beings above ground and heavens. The Crown of the tree is in heaven, the kingdom of gods and rain. Tamoanchan was represented by the Ceiba tree.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 8 - Warfare: Trophy Heads === The "Guerra Florida " (flower war) was one of the main religious practices associated with the Tecoxquines. The aim was not to conquer. Rather, get warriors prisoners for ritual sacrifice, and whose heads were cut and then offered to the gods. These wars were usually produced locally, but also conducted in places as far away as the Talpa and Mascota Valleys and Mochitiltic Canyon in Jalisco.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 9 – Tlalocan=== water was thought to be underground in ancient Mesoamerica, hence the underworld was considered a fertile place. Tlalocan was the "water"paradise underground. It was inhabited by the “Chanes”, or water spirits, as well as the spirits of people drowned or whose death was water related. Tlalocan also was the site of the legendary crocodile [[Cipactli]],<ref>in Aztec mythology; Cipactli was a voracious, primitive and monstrous creature, half crocodile, half fish. It was always hungry, and in each joint of its 18 bodies had a mouth adorning it. Tezcatlipoca sacrificed a foot, using it as bait to attract it. It is also the first day of the sacred Aztec calendar, Tonalpohualli.</ref> a "earth monster", symbolizing fertility.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 10 – The Devoted Christ === The first historical references of the archaeological site of Altavista date from 1612. These describe many crosses, and above all, a devout Christ that local people venerates. This is possibly a reference to the "corn man", a figure that symbolizes fertility and growth. Local farmers leave offerings of candles and gourd bowls of salt to this figure in order to obtain fertility for their coffee and tobacco crops.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 11 – The Apostle Matthew === During the early 17TH century, Spaniards believed that the Apostle Matthew traveled to the new world in prehispanic times to evangelize natives. This is thought to explain the crosses engraved in the Altavista rocks.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 12 – The Cross === For Tecoxquines, as well as for most ancient Mesoamerican, the cross actually was a mental map of the cosmos. Symbolizes five sacred directions: the four cardinal points and the center. Each is associated with certain gods, colors, and sacred kingdoms, as well as each of the four trees that formed the tamoanchan kingdoms. The idea of the universe of four corners is still present among native Mexico today, symbolized by crosses, diamonds and other similar forms.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 13 – Communication With The Gods === The Altavista rocks were probably associated with the mythical [[Tamoanchan]] trees connecting the underworld, earth and heaven. The prayers of the people went up through the sap of the trunks into the realm of the gods. In turn, the gifts of the gods, rain, fertility and good health returned to land the same way. For the Tecoxquines the Altavista rocks would have served the same purpose, a means of communication between the people and their gods.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 14 – Tecoxquin Symbolism === Spirals, wavy lines, and other symbols carved in the Altavista rocks probably constitute a ritual prayer language for the gods. As an agricultural culture, the Tocoxquines would have been concerned with rain, fertility of the land and the continuity of the seasonal rhythms that they relied on. While the exact meaning of symbols will never be known, spirals have been interpreted as the Sun, storm, the wind, the spiral snake, or as a symbol of the natural cycle of station rainy and dry.<ref name=Richard />
===Sign 15 –Huichol Offerings=== Huichol natives occasionally visit Altavista originally lived in the Nayar mountains, recently a group moved to the Las Varas area. They present offerings and perform ceremonies for Nakahue, "our fertility grandmother" and Tatevari, "our grandfather of fire". Some Huicholes also travel to the nearby Chacala Port, where ancient petroglyphs are present and leave offerings for Tatei Aramara “our mother Ocean”.<ref name=Richard />
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Association of Polish Artists and Designers

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Association of Polish Artists and Designers | image = ZPAP-Warsaw(Nowy-Swiat7).jpg | size = 260px | alt = ZPAP main office in Warsaw | caption = ZPAP main office in [[Warsaw]] | abbreviation = ZPAP | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | headquarters = Warsaw, kamienica Efrosa at ul. [[Nowy Świat]] 7 | coords = {{coord|52|14|30|N|21|00|56|E|}} | language = [[Polish language|Polish]] | leader_name = | former name = |www = http://www.zpap.org.pl }} The '''Association of Polish Artists and Designers''' ({{lang|pl|Związek Polskich Artystów Plastyków}}, ZPAP) is an official association of professional artists in [[Poland]], representing more than 8,500 learned artists working in the field of [[visual arts]], including: painting, sculpture, graphic design, interior and set design, ceramics, fabric arts, as well as new media, and [[art restoration]].
The Association was founded in 1911 in [[Kraków]] during the [[Partitions of Poland]]. In [[Polish culture in the Interbellum|the interwar period]] until 1939 it served as a trade union and in 1945, following World War II, it was formally re-established as an association.<ref>Glenn Sujo, [https://books.google.com/books?id=y7WuzDK3dSkC&pg=PA111&dq=ZPAP ''Legacies of Silence''.] Published by New Age Publishers, 2001; 127 pages. {{ISBN|0-85667-534-2}}.</ref><ref>[http://www.artluk.com/onas.php ''artluk'' Magazine] with funds by [[Ministry of Culture and National Heritage of the Republic of Poland|Polish Ministry of Culture and Art]]. {{en icon}} {{pl icon}}</ref> In 1980, ZPAP supported the [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity movement]] and opposed the imposition of [[Martial law in Poland|martial law in 1981]]. Consequently, the military authorities disbanded the Association when it refused to retract its [[communiqué]]s.<ref>Umbrella Magazine, [https://books.google.com/books?id=FGlUAAAAMAAJ&q=1982+%22The+suspension+of+ZPAP,+reported+by+the+official+press,+was+ordered+after+it+refused+to+retract+eight+communiques+released+in+the+last+year%22&dq=1982+%22The+suspension+of+ZPAP,+reported+by+the+official+press,+was+ordered+after+it+refused+to+retract+eight+communiques+released+in+the+last+year%22&pgis=1 Item notes: v. 5-7, page 68.] Published by Umbrella Associates, U.S., 1982</ref><ref>Joanna Inglot, [https://books.google.com/books?id=RnAaq6ws_kMC&pg=PA94&dq=%22the+majority+of+artists+joined+in+the+widespread+national+effort+to+break+the+party-state+monopoly%22#PPA95,M1 ''The Figurative Sculpture of Magdalena Abakanowicz''], page 95. Published by University of California Press, 2004; 154 pages. {{nobreak|{{ISBN|0-520-23125-2}}}}.</ref> ZPAP operated unofficially until the [[History of Poland (1989–present)|restoration of democracy]] in 1989. Today, ZPAP features prominently across the country with 23 regional Chapters, paid staff, curators, publications, and regional art galleries promoting work of its members.<ref name="IAM">Instytut Adama Mickiewicza, [http://www.culture.pl/pl/culture/artykuly/in_or_zpap "Sztuki wizualne: Związek Polskich Artystów Plastyków"] at www.culture.pl ISSN 1734-0624 Nr 2628</ref>
==Structure== ZPAP membership is limited to graduates of art faculties of relevant institutions of higher learning, with the main emphasis on regional Academies of Fine Arts. On top of its creative presence in major Polish cities, the Association operates two professional development retreats, in [[Ustka]] and in [[Świnoujście]].<ref name="IAM" /> It sponsors dozens of commercial art galleries across Poland as well as selected stores with professional art supplies. ZPAP organizes a number of annual events, and offers its own [[Jan Cybis]] Award for creative achievement. In 1996 the Association organized the UNESCO conference around the international status of an artist.<ref name="IAM" /> It is the leading advocacy group working in conjunction with the Polish governmental agencies regulating labor laws applicable to practising art professionals. ZPAP is represented in the World Executive Committee of the [[International Association of Art]] (IAA).<ref name="zpap.org">[http://www.zpap.org.pl/index.php?IdKat=1003010018&IdKat2=1157655602 Official webpage of The Association of Polish Artists and Designers] {{en icon}} {{pl icon}}</ref>
Since 1996, ZPAP manages copyrights of about 1,000 members and is in charge of issuing licenses for the commercial use of their artwork. The economic nonprofit activity of the Association is geared toward generating funds necessary for the maintaining of its venues, as well as providing financial support for members in need.<ref name="zpap.org"/>
The main office of ZPAP is in [[Warsaw]] and is located at the upper floor of the historic [[Kamienica (architecture)|kamienica]] Efrosa at [[Nowy Świat Street|ul. Nowy Świat]] 7 ''(pictured)'', where Princes of the [[Lubomirski family]] once lived in the 18th century. The building was rebuilt with its original [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] portal intact following wartime destruction of the Polish capital.<ref name="zpap.org"/>
Regional chapters of ZPAP are located in the following cities: [[Białystok]], [[Bielsko-Biała]], [[Bydgoszcz]], [[Częstochowa]], [[Gdańsk]], [[Katowice]], [[Kielce]], [[Koszalin]], [[Kraków]], [[Lublin]], [[Łódź]], [[Olsztyn]], [[Opole]], [[Poznań]], [[Radom]], [[Rzeszów]], [[Szczecin]], [[Toruń]], [[Warszawa]], [[Wrocław]], [[Zakopane]], [[Zielona Góra]], and [[Gliwice]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Feminism and the arts]]; added [[Category:Feminist art organizations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Bad Girrls Studios''' was a popular [[Boston]] [[Art gallery|gallery]] and performance space from 1996 to 2000, located at 209 Green Street in Jamaica Plain. Founded by [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|School of the Museum of Fine Arts]] student Jessica Brand, the [[artist-run]] studio hosted numerous events until it closed due to pressure from the [[Boston Licensing Commission]] and lack of funding.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2004/03/04/no_alternative/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=No alternative | first=Geoff | last=Edgers | date=March 4, 2004}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=98915 The Harvard Crimson :: Arts :: The Field Guide: Art in Boston<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>http://users.rcn.com/kyp/dog.html Putting Shakespeare's Dog to Sleep</ref>
Bad Girrls Studios supported [[female]] artists in particular, and art that pushed boundaries of [[sexual orientation]] and [[gender identity]], the largest of which was a 1998 exhibit "Naughty Girrls Nite @ Bad Girrls Studios", produced by studio member Rebecca Goldberg, which drew over 50 women artists and performers from [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[New England]].
Several of the studio members were also co-founders or members of the [[Art School Cheerleaders]]. This performance art group, which began at the [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|School of the Museum of Fine Arts]], used Cheerleading as a medium for satirical commentary about art and the art world, and to advocate for arts funding.
The artist-run gallery was partially inspired by another important [[performance art]] space in Boston during that time, [[Mobius Artists Group]], that brought cutting-edge performance artists to Boston through an international exchange program. Mobius had been founded by another member of the [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|School of the Museum of Fine Arts]] community, instructor Marilyn Arsem.
Bad Girrls Studios operated under the slogan "Art is Not A Luxury."
== References ==
<references/> *{{cite news |first=David |last=Wildman |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=BAD GIRRLS STUDIOS FIGHTS FOR SPACE\ ARTS GROUP DENOUNCES LANDLORDS' DEMANDS |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BG&p_theme=bg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADDE52061F0304&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work=Boston Globe |publisher= |date= May 14, 2000 |accessdate=2008-04-26 }}

{{see also|Our Lady of Sorrows, Queen of Poland}} {{Infobox Catholic apparition |name = Black Madonna of Częstochowa
Our Lady of Częstochowa |image = NMP-Czestochowska-w-koronie.jpg |location = [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]] |date = Attested as early as 14th century |type = Wooden icon, bejewelled |approval = [[Pope Clement XI]]
[[Pope Pius X]]
[[Pope John Paul II]] |shrine = [[Jasna Góra Monastery]], [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]]
[[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa]], [[Doylestown, Pennsylvania]] |attributes = [[Black Madonna]] in [[Hodegetria]] form, [[Infant Jesus]], fleur-de-lis robes, slashes on right cheek |patronage = [[Poland]] }} The '''Black Madonna of Częstochowa''' ({{lang-pl|Czarna Madonna}} or {{lang|pl|Matka Boska Częstochowska|italic=yes}}, {{lang-la|Imago thaumaturga Beatae Virginis Mariae Immaculatae Conceptae, in Claro Monte}} ), also known as '''Our Lady of Częstochowa''', is a revered [[icon]] of the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] housed at the [[Jasna Góra Monastery]] in [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]]. Several Pontiffs have recognised the venerated icon, beginning with [[Pope Clement XI]] who issued a [[Canonical Coronation]] to the image on 8 September 1717 via the Vatican Chapter. ==The icon== The four-foot-high painting displays a traditional composition well known in the icons of Eastern Christians. The Virgin Mary is shown as the "[[Hodegetria]]" ("One Who Shows the Way"). In it the Virgin directs attention away from herself, gesturing with her right hand toward Jesus as the source of salvation. In turn, the child extends his right hand toward the viewer in blessing while holding a book of gospels in his left hand. The icon shows the Madonna in [[fleur-de-lis]] robes. The origins of the icon and the date of its composition are still contested among scholars.[http://www.csicop.org/si/show/the_black_madonna_a_folkloristic_and_iconographic_investigation/ ''The Black Madonna: A Folkloristic and Iconographic Investigation''. Skeptical Inquirer. September/October 2015.] One difficulty in dating the icon is due in part to its original image being painted over after being badly damaged by [[Hussite]] raiders in 1430. The wooden boards that backed the painting were broken and the canvas slashed. [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] restorers unfamiliar with the [[encaustic painting|encaustic method]] found that the paints they applied to the damaged areas "simply sloughed off the image" according to the medieval chronicler Risinius, and their solution was to erase the original image and to repaint it on the original panel. The original features of an Orthodox icon were softened; the nose was made more aquiline. ==History== [[File:Nuestra Señora de Czestochowa recubierta de Orfebrería.jpg|thumb|The image of the Holy Virgin of Częstochowa (before 1714). The collection of [[Radomysl Castle]][http://www.radozamok.com.ua/en/ The Official Site of Radomysl Castle]]] ===Lucan tradition=== The icon of [[Blessed Virgin Mary|Our Lady]] of Częstochowa has been intimately associated with Poland for the past 600 years. Its history prior to its arrival in Poland is shrouded in numerous legends which trace the icon's origin to [[Luke the Evangelist|St. Luke]] who painted it on a cedar table top from the house of the [[Holy Family]].{{cite web|url=https://udayton.edu/imri/mary/c/czestochowa-black-madonna.php|title=Black Madonnas: Our Lady of Czestochowa|date=2008-03-26|last=Duricy|first=Michael P|publisher=The Marian Library/International Marian Research Institute, Dayton, Ohio - [[University of Dayton]]|accessdate=2008-12-05}} {{cite news| author=Zenon Zawada| work=Ukraine Observer| title=EASTERN APPROACHES - The Black Madonna|url=http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/217/814 | date=2008-01-26|accessdate=2008-12-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080126124229/http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/217/814 |archivedate = 2008-01-26}} The same legend holds that the painting was discovered in Jerusalem in 326 by St. [[Helena (empress)|Helena]], who brought it back to [[Constantinople]] and presented it to her son, [[Constantine the Great]].[http://www.franciscancaring.org/blackmadonnashri.html#ABriefHistory "Black Madonna Shrine", Franciscan Missionary Brothers] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140829025421/http://www.franciscancaring.org/blackmadonnashri.html#ABriefHistory |date=August 29, 2014 }} ===Arrival in Częstochowa=== The oldest documents from [[Jasna Góra Monastery|Jasna Góra]] state that the picture travelled from Constantinople via [[Belz]]. Eventually it came into the possession of [[Vladislaus II of Opole|Władysław Opolczyk]], [[Duke of Opole]], and adviser to [[Louis I of Hungary|Louis of Anjou]], King of Poland and Hungary. Ukrainian sources state that earlier in its history it was brought to Belz with much ceremony and honors by King [[Leo I of Galicia|Lev I of Galicia]] and later taken by Władysław from the Castle of Belz, when the town was incorporated into the Polish kingdom. A popular story tells that in late August 1384, Ladislaus was passing Częstochowa with the picture when his horses refused to go on. He was advised in a dream to leave the icon at Jasna Gora. Art historians say that the original painting was a Byzantine icon created around the sixth or ninth century. They agree that Prince Władysław brought it to the monastery in the 14th century.[http://www.polamjournal.com/Library/APHistory/blackmadonna/blackmadonna.html "The Black Madonna of Czestochowa", ''Polish American Journal''] ==Pontifical approbations== Several Pontiffs have recognized the image, namely the following: * [[Pope Clement XI]] issued a [[Canonical Coronation]] for the image through the Vatican Chapter on 8 September 1717 * [[Pope Pius X]], after the crowns were stolen on 23 October 1909, the Pontiff replaced the crowns on 22 May 1910. * [[Pope John Paul II]] gifted another set of crowns as a native of Poland, which was placed on 26 August 2005. ===Coronation as Queen and Protectress of Poland=== In August 1382 the hilltop parish church was transferred to the Paulites, a hermitic order from Hungary. The golden fleur-de-lis painted on the Virgin's blue veil parallel the heraldic ''azure, semée de lis, or'' of the French royal coat of arms and the most likely explanation for their presence is that the icon had been present in Hungary during the reign of either [[Charles I of Hungary]] and/or [[Louis the Great]], the Hungarian kings of the [[Anjou]] dynasty, who probably had the fleur-de-lis of their family's coat of arms painted on the icon. This would suggest that the icon was probably originally brought to Jasna Gora by the Pauline monks from their founding monastery in Hungary. The Black Madonna is said to have miraculously saved the monastery of Jasna Góra (English: Bright Mount) from a Swedish invasion. The Siege of Jasna Góra took place in the winter of 1655 during the [[Second Northern War]], as the Swedish invasion of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] is known. The Swedes were attempting to capture the Jasna Góra monastery in Częstochowa. Seventy monks and 180 local volunteers, mostly from the szlachta (Polish nobility), held off 4,000 Swedes for 40 days, saved their sacred icon and, according to some accounts, turned the course of the war. This event led King [[John II Casimir Vasa]] to "crown" Our Lady of Częstochowa ("the [[Black Madonna]]") as [[Lwów Oath|Queen and Protector of Poland]] in the cathedral of [[Lviv|Lwów]] on April 1, 1652. Prior to this event, several royal nobilities have offered crowns to the image throughout the years, replacing its iron sheet crown by gold and several jewels. In later years, various jewels were interchanged and repositioned around the image to preserve the aesthetic of the icon with the replacement of stolen crowns.http://sunday.niedziela.pl/artykul.php?dz=polska&id_art=00163 ===Legends about the Madonna's appearance=== {{RC-Mariology}} [[File:Jasna Gora - Czarna Madonna (mozaika).jpg|thumb|right|Black Madonna mosaic at Jasna Góra.]] The legend concerning the two scars on the Black Madonna's right cheek is that the [[Hussite]]s stormed the Pauline monastery in 1430, plundering the sanctuary. Among the items stolen was the icon. After putting it in their wagon, the Hussites tried to get away but their horses refused to move. They threw the portrait down to the ground and one of the plunderers drew his sword upon the image and inflicted two deep strikes. When the robber tried to inflict a third strike, he fell to the ground and writhed in agony until his death. Despite past attempts to repair these scars, they had difficulty in covering up those slashes as the painting was done with tempera infused with diluted wax. ===Veneration=== Częstochowa is regarded as the most popular shrine in Poland, with many Polish Catholics making a pilgrimage there every year. A pilgrimage has left Warsaw every August 6 since 1711 for the nine-day, 140-mile trek. Elderly pilgrims recall stealing through the dark countryside at great personal risk during the German Nazi occupation. Pope John Paul II secretly visited as a student pilgrim during World War II.[https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/22/travel/poland-s-black-madonna.html Menaker, Drusilla. "Poland's Black Madonna", ''New York Times'', July 22, 1990] The feast day of Our Lady of Częstochowa is celebrated on August 26.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}} The American [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa]] is located in Doylestown, Pennsylvania.[http://www.czestochowa.us/content/view/1319/65/ "National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa] ==In other countries== [[File:Jasnajf.JPG|thumb|200px|Black Madonna of Częstochowa (at [[National Shrine of The Divine Mercy, Philippines]]).]] Orthodox Christians are also aware of the Black Madonna of Częstochowa and venerate her. The icon is popular in Ukraine and Belarus as former parts of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and even in Russia. Moreover, this icon has an Orthodox origin, but Polish historians have found out it has been repainted at least twice and there is almost nothing left of the previous Byzantine manner of painting.A. Różycka-Bryzek, J. Gadomski, Obraz Matki Boskiej Częstochowskiej w świetle badań historii sztuki, "Studia Claromontana" 5, 1984, s. 27-52 [[Ukrainians]] have a special devotion for the Madonna of Częstochowa. The icon is often mentioned in Ukrainian folk songs from the 16th and 17th centuries. ==See also== * [[Black Madonna]] * [[Jasna Góra Monastery]] * [[Black Madonna Shrine, Missouri]] * [[National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa|National Shrine of Our Lady of Częstochowa]] * [[Orthodox Church of the Icon of Our Lady of Częstochowa]] * [[Deluge (history)|The Deluge]], Swedish invasion * [[Our Lady of Sorrows, Queen of Poland]] * [[Erzulie Dantor]] ==References and sources== ===References=== {{reflist|2}} ===Sources=== * {{cite web|url=http://www.jasnagora.pl|title=Jasna Góra|publisher=[[copyright|©]]1998-2008 Copyright by Klasztor OO. Paulinów Jasna Góra - Częstochowa |accessdate=October 22, 2008}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.ksiegarnia.bernardinum.com.pl/Czestochowska_Hodegetria-170.html|title=Częstochowska Hodegetria|last=[[:pl:Wojciech Kurpik|Kurpik, Wojciech]]|first=|publisher=Wydawnictwo Konserwatorów Dzieł Sztuki, Wydawnictwo Bernardinum |location=Łódź-Pelplin|year=2008 |pages=302|language=Polish, English, Hungarian}} ==External links== {{commons category|Black Madonna of Częstochowa}} * [http://www.jasnagora.pl/ Jasna Góra] * [http://www.czestochowa.us/ Czestochowa.us] * [[:pl:Wojciech Kurpik|biographical entry of prof. dr Wojciech Kurpik, restorer of Black Madonna of Częstochowa (Polish Wikipedia)]] {{National symbols of Poland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Madonna Of Czestochowa, The}} [[Category:Częstochowa]] [[Category:Marian shrines]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Poland]] [[Category:Catholic devotions]] [[Category:Black Madonna of Częstochowa| ]] [[Category:Titles of Mary]] [[Category:National symbols of Poland]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox icons of the Virgin Mary]] [[Category:Paintings of the Madonna and Child]] [[Category:Pauline Order]] [[Category:Angels in art]]

{{italic title}} '''''Cartoonists Remember 9/11''''' is a series of [[comic strip]]s run on the tenth anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]] on the United States. It includes cartoonists from [[King Features Syndicate]], [[Creators Syndicate]], [[Tribune Media Services]], [[Universal Press Syndicate]] and [[Washington Post Writers Group]].
The works are being exhibited at the [[Newseum]] in Washington, D.C., the [[Cartoon Art Museum]] in San Francisco, the [[ToonSeum]] in Pittsburgh, New York City's [[Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art]] (MoCCA) and the [[Society of Illustrators]] in New York City.
==Participating strips== * [[Agnes (comic strip)|''Agnes'']] * ''[[Apartment 3-G]]'' * [[Archie (comic strip)|''Archie'']] (see [[Archie (comics)|''Archie'']]) * [[Arctic Circle (comic strip)|''Arctic Circle'']] * ''[[Ask Shagg]]'' * [[B.C. {{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox artist | name = Clarissa Munger Badger | image = Clarissa Munger Badger.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Clarissa Munger | birth_date = 1806 <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living artists, {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} for dead. For living people supply only the year unless the exact date is already WIDELY published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. Treat such cases as if only the year is known, so use {{birth year and age|YYYY}} or a similar option. --> | birth_place = [[Madison, Connecticut|East Guilford]], Connecticut | death_date = 1889 <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = West Cemetery, [[Madison, Connecticut]] | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = American | known_for = botanical painting | spouse = Milton Badger }}
'''Clarissa Munger Badger''' (1806–1889) was a mid 19th century American [[botanical illustrator]] best known for three volumes of flower paintings accompanied by poetry. She also painted on textiles.
==Family== [[File:Clarissa-Badger tulips-1867.jpg|thumb|Clarissa Munger Badger, lithograph of tulips from her 1867 book ''Floral Belles from the Green-House and Garden''.]] Clarissa W. Munger was born in [[Madison, Connecticut|East Guilford]], Connecticut, in 1806 to [[George Munger (artist)|George Munger]], a portrait painter and engraver, and Parnel Kelsey Munger.<ref name=mcb/><ref name=mhs/> Clarissa, her older brother George, and her younger sister Caroline all become artists as well, with Caroline specializing in portraits like her father and Clarissa in botanical art.<ref name=mds/><ref name=jk/>
In 1828, she married the Rev. [[Milton Badger]], who was a minister in [[Andover, Massachusetts]] and later became the associate secretary of the [[American Home Missionary Society]], a job requiring him to spend time in the western United States.<ref name=slb/><ref name=cq/> They had five children, of whom two survived to adulthood, both becoming doctors.<ref name=slb/> Milton developed [[Bright's disease]], and the couple moved back Madison, Connecticut, where Clarissa was widowed in 1873.<ref name=cq/>
==Works== In 1848, Clarissa Munger Badger privately published ''A Forget-Me-Not: Flowers from Nature with Selected Poetry'' under the name '''C. M. Badger'''. This was a volume of poetry by [[William Cullen Bryant]], [[Lydia Sigourney]], [[Mary Howitt]], and others illustrated with 13 of her flower paintings. This may have provided a model for her 1859 book ''Wild Flowers Drawn and Colored from Nature'' (informally known as ''The Wild Flowers of America''), which was illustrated with 22 plates of individual common flowers such as [[trailing arbutus]], [[purple violet]], [[cardinal flower]], and [[harebell]].<ref name=mds/> It also included poems, thought in this case to have been written by Badger herself, together with an introductory poem by Sigourney.<ref name=mhs/> The poet [[Emily Dickinson]] owned a copy of this book.<ref name=jf/> The plates were widely reproduced at the time, contributing to Badger's reputation as a top-rank botanical artist.<ref name=mhs/>
Clarissa's third book, ''Floral Belles from the Green-House and Garden'', was published in 1867 with 16 hand-colored lithographic plates typically showing two or three flowers in clusters or bouquets. As with her first book, the flower paintings were accompanied by poetry, in this case poems about the flowers depicted.
A sketch written when Badger was 75 remarks on the "feeling and delicacy" of her watercolors and remarks that she was still painting flowers at that advanced age.<ref name=slb/> The popularity of Badger's graceful, stylized paintings in her own day was "dwarfed by her male counterparts; only now is she being applauded as a fine botanical artist".<ref name=jk/>
Recent research has revealed that Badger also painted on textiles. Extant works include a quilt with some panels featuring hand-painted flowers, and a silk scarf with roses painted at one end and [[morning glories]] at the other.<ref name=mhs/>
Portraits of Badger and her husband were painted in 1846-47 by [[Nathaniel Jocelyn]].<ref name=mhs/>
{{commons category|Clarissa Munger Badger}}
==References== {{reflist | refs=
<ref name=mhs>[https://madisonhistory.org/key-figures/clarissa-munger-badger/]. Madison Historical Society website.</ref>
<ref name=mcb>Bowman, Mira Chittenden, and Marjorie Lee Chittenden. "The Munger Sisters". Philip S. Platt, ed., ''Madison's Heritage''. Madison, CT: Madison Historical Society, 1964.</ref>
<ref name=jf>Farr, Judith. ''The Gardens of Emily Dickinson''. Harvard University Press, 2005.</ref>
<ref name=mds>Schroeder, Michael D. [http://www.d.umn.edu/tma/mungersite/FramesVar.html?OtherMungers.html "Other 19th and Early 20th C. Artists with Surname 'Munger'"]. The Gilbert Munger Web Site, August 256, 2006.</ref>
<ref name=slb>Bailey, Sarah Loring. ''Historical Sketches of Andover (Comprising the Present Towns of North Andover and Andover), Massachusetts''. Ulan Press, 2012.</ref>
<ref name=cq>Coe, D.B. "Milton Badger". ''The Congregational Quarterly'', vol. 17, no. 1 (January 1875), pp. 11-12.</ref>
<ref name=jk>Kramer, Jack. ''Women of Flowers: A Tribute to Victorian Women Illustrators''. Stewart, Tabori & Chang, 1996.</ref>
}}
== External links == * [https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:45827046$6i ''The Wild Flowers of America''] digitized by Harvard University * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/madisonhistory/albums/72157672432287733 Flickr album of work by Clarissa Munger Badger] from Madison Historical Society * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/madisonhistory/31058896166/in/album-72157672432287733/ Portrait of Clarissa Munger Badger]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Badger, Clarissa Munger}} [[Category:1806 births]] [[Category:Botanical illustrators]] [[Category:Artists from Connecticut]] [[Category:19th-century women artists]] [[Category:1889 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American painters]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of Cameroon |image = Coat of arms of Cameroon.svg |image_width = 200px |middle = Coat of arms of Cameroon old.svg |middle_width = 150px |middle_caption = Old version |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image3 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = [[Republic of Cameroon]] |year_adopted = 1986 |crest = |torse = |shield = Per pile gules, Vert, and Or; per pale a mullet Or and the scales of justice sable with pans argent superimposed on a map of Cameroon azure. |supporters = Two fasces in saltire proper |compartment = |motto = '''Paix, Travail, Patrie'''
(French: "Peace, Work, Fatherland") |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = |}} The '''coat of arms of [[Cameroon]]''' consists of a shield with a banner above and below it. Behind the shield are two crossed [[fasces]]. The shield has the same color pattern as the [[flag of Cameroon]], and in the center is a map of the nation. The scales of justice are superimposed on top of the map of the nation. ==Description== The banner at the bottom gives the name of the nation in [[French language|French]] and [[English language|English]]. The top banner contains the national [[motto]]: {{Lang|fr|Paix, Travail, Patrie}}. The fasces are a symbol of the republic's authority, and the scales of justice represent justice.[http://www.ngw.nl/int/afr/cm-nat.htm National arms of Cameroon] The previous version of the state arms had text in French only, with "République du Cameroun – 1er Janvier 1960" on a scroll above the shield, and "Paix, Travail, Patrie" below the shield. The shield differed in that the green and yellow areas to left and right each had one large blue five-pointed star, while the central red area did not have a star on top (so that the blue map outline of Cameroon extended higher).''Guide to the Flags of the World'' by Mauro Talocci, revised and updated by Whitney Smith ({{ISBN|0-688-01141-1}}), p. 144. == Earlier coats of arms == ===Proposed arms 1914=== In 1914, the German government decided to assign coats of arms to its overseas colonies, including Cameroon. Arms were designed, but [[World War I]] broke out before the project was finalised, and the arms were never actually taken into use. Giving the colonies their own insignia in time of war could let them have a symbol to rally around in case of rebellion. The arms proposed for [[Kamerun|the Imperial Colony of Cameroon]] depicted an elephant's head and the German imperial eagle on a chief. The eagle and the imperial crown on the shield was the same for all the proposed colonial arms.Schurdel, H.D. . Battenberg (1995). ''Flaggen & Wappen Deutschland - Heraldik, Hymnen, BRD & DDR Flaggen und Wappen, Deutsche Ostgebiete, ehem. deutsche Kolonien u.v.m.'' == Other coats of arms == File:British Cameroons Seal.svg|Coat of arms of [[British Cameroons]] (1922-1961) File:Proposed Coat of Arms Cameroon 1914.png|[[Coats of arms of German colonies|Proposed coat of arms]] of [[German Cameroon]] (1914) ==See also== *[[Flag of Cameroon]] *[[Coats of arms of German colonies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Coats of arms of Cameroon}} {{Coat of arms of Africa}} [[Category:National symbols of Cameroon]] [[Category:National coats of arms|Cameroon]] [[Category:Coats of arms with the fasces|Cameroon]] [[Category:Coats of arms with weighing scales]] [[Category:Coats of arms with stars|Cameroon]] [[Category:Coats of arms with maps|Cameroon]] {{Cameroon-stub}} {{Heraldry-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=April 2016}} '''Covering cherub''' (in literary usage) is the [[Anxiety of influence|obstructing presence]] for the artist of the inherited tradition, and cultural predecessors, with which they are faced.
==Origins== Found originally in [[Ezekiel]], the covering cherub was adapted for use by (among others) both [[John Milton|Milton]] and [[William Blake]]. In the [[William Blake's mythology|Blakean vision]], the covering cherub was a composite but always negative figure of truth's guardian turned destructive,<ref>D. Erdman, ''The Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake'' (2008) p. 944 and p. 926</ref> of a cruel and hardened Selfhood;<ref>N.Marsh, ''William Blake: The Poems'' (2012) p. 36</ref> and it was from Blake that in 1967 [[Harold Bloom]] derived his concept of the covering cherub as a literary/cultural barrier. Apparently, a waking nightmare he experienced gave rise first to his poem on the subject, "The Covering Cherub", and eventually to his book [[Anxiety of Influence|''The Anxiety of Influence'']].<ref>[http://hilobrow.com/2013/07/11/harold-bloom/ Harold Bloom]</ref>
==Thematics== For Bloom, "the Covering Cherub then is a demon of continuity...cultural history, the dead poets, the embarrassments of a tradition grown too wealthy to need anything more".<ref>H. Bloom, ''The Anxiety of Influence'' (1973) p. 39 and p. 21</ref> Bloom considered the artistic struggle in [[Freud]]ian terms, as a filial contest with a [[father figure]] carrying cultural authority<ref>J. Childers ed., ''The Columbia Dictionary of Modern Literary and Cultural Criticism'' (1995) p. 14</ref> – an [[Oedipal conflict]] with a [[superego]] either originally modelled on a cultural hero<ref>L. Hudson/B. Jarot, ''The Way Men Think'' (1993) p. 44</ref> or influenced subsequently by such an ideal model.<ref>S. Freud, ''New Introductory Lectures on Psychoanalysis'' (PFL 2) p. 96</ref>
Though initially referencing a patriarchal father/son interaction, the concept of the covering cherub has also been applied to works by women writers such as [[Angela Carter]]<ref>''Bluebeard Gothic'' (2012)</ref> and [[Virginia Woolf]].<ref>M. Keane, ''John Milton's Paradise Lost'' (2013) p. 75</ref>
==Criticism== Critics have seen Bloom's central image as too open-ended to serve as analyical tool, a vague series of analogies only tenuously working as Bloom desired.<ref>J. Doane, ''Nostalgia and Sexual Difference'' (2013) p. 90-1</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| *[[Sandra Gilbert#"The Anxiety of Authorship"|Anxiety of Authorship]] *[[Artaud]] *[[High culture]] *[[Northrop Frye]] *[[Tharmas]] *[[Wallace Stevens]] *[[Western canon]] }}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://newabstraction.net/2012/02/16/angelus-novus/ Angelus novus]

revision.comment: /* History */ Unlikely to be staying at Hawkins aged 6 - chronologise a bit better
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{coord|51|30|32|N|0|08|34|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox street | name = Dover Street | native_name = | marker_image = | image = Dover Street - geograph.org.uk - 1592055.jpg | caption = View of Dover Street looking northwards towards Grafton Street | other_name = | former_names = | postal_code = {{postcode|W|1}} | metro_system=Tube | metro ={{rail-interchange|london|underground}} {{lus|Green Park}} | addresses = | length_m = | length_ft = | length_mi = 0.1 | length_km = | length_ref = {{cite web|title=Driving directions to Dover St|url=https://maps.google.co.uk/maps?saddr=50+Dover+St,+London,+Greater+London+W1S,+UK&daddr=Dover+St&hl=en&sll=51.508455,-0.142227&sspn=0.002087,0.004941&geocode=FVLxEQMdxtf9_ylH7sDaKQV2SDHljkYf8lJIVg%3BFTH4EQMdAdH9_w&t=h&mra=mift&mrsp=1&sz=18&z=18|publisher=[[Google]]|accessdate=6 October 2013}} | width = | location = Mayfair, London | client = | maint = | coordinates = | direction_a = south | terminus_a = [[Piccadilly]]
{{coord|51.5075|-0.1414}} | direction_b = north | terminus_b = Grafton Street
{{coord|51.5093|-0.1431}} | junction = | commissioning_date = | construction_start_date = 1683 | completion_date = | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | north = | south = | west = | east = }} [[File:Dover Street, North of Piccadilly (1772).jpg|thumb|Example of Georgian architecture in Dover Street]] [[File:The Ritz on Piccadilly.jpg|thumb|The [[The Ritz London Hotel|Ritz Hotel]] is opposite Dover Street]] '''Dover Street''' is a street in [[Mayfair]], London. The street is notable for its [[Georgian architecture]] as well as the location of historic London clubs and hotels, which have been frequented by world leaders and historic figures in the arts. It also hosts a number of contemporary art galleries. An equestrian sculpture by [[Elisabeth Frink]] stands on the junction of Dover Street and [[Piccadilly]], opposite the [[The Ritz London Hotel|Ritz Hotel]]. == Location == The street lies in the south of Mayfair in the [[West End of London|West End]]. To the south-east, the street adjoins the major thoroughfare of [[Piccadilly]]. To the north-west, it continues as Grafton Street. To the north-east is [[Albemarle Street]], running parallel with Dover Street and the location of the [[Royal Institution]]. South-west is [[Berkeley Street]] (adjoining [[Berkeley Square]] to the north), also running in parallel. The nearest tube station is [[Green Park tube station|Green Park]]. == History == Dover Street was built by a syndicate of developers headed by [[Sir Thomas Bond, 1st Baronet|Sir Thomas Bond]]. The syndicate purchased a Piccadilly mansion called [[Clarendon House]] from [[Christopher Monck, 2nd Duke of Albemarle]] in 1683 and proceeded to demolish the house and develop the area. At that time the house backed onto open fields and the development of the various estates in Mayfair was just getting underway. The syndicate also built [[Bond Street]] and [[Albemarle Street]]. In June 1797 [[John Nash (architect)|John Nash]] moved into 28 Dover Street a building of his own design, he built an even bigger house next door at 29 into which he moved the following year.John Sumerson, ''The Life and Work of John Nash Architect'', 1980, George Allen & Unwin, page 30 [[Edward Moxon]] moved from premises he had established in 1830 in [[New Bond Street]] to 44 Dover Street. He published [[William Wordsworth|Wordsworth]] from 1835 onwards and in 1839 issued the first complete edition of [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]]'s poems. In 1841, he was found guilty of [[blasphemy]] for passages in Shelley's ''[[Queen Mab]]''. [[Anne Lister]] (1791–1840), a notable Victorian landowner and diarist, liked to stay at Hawkins, located at 26 Dover Street. {{cite web|author = Hazel Brothers|date = 2003 |title = "Anne Lister in London 1819-1839" (2 pages) |work = From History to Her Story, Yorkshire Women's Lives On-Line |url = http://www.historytoherstory.org.uk/index.php?targetid=84 |accessdate = 26 July 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928225641/http://www.historytoherstory.org.uk/index.php?targetid=84 |archivedate = 28 September 2007 |df = dmy-all}} [[Brown's Hotel]] (then termed a "genteel inn") was established in 1837 by James Brown, [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]]'s valet, who took a lease on 23 Dover Street to cater for those who were in town "for the Season". He ran it with his wife, Sarah Willis, the personal maid of [[Anne Isabella Byron, Baroness Byron|Lady Byron]], who gave financial support. The hotel was later enlarged and joined with backing premises on Albemarle Street. In 1876, [[Alexander Graham Bell]] made the first successful telephone call in Britain from the hotel. In 1890, The International Niagara Commission met in the hotel and their decision on distributing "[[Niagara Falls#Power|Niagara power]]" subsequently led to the adoption of the alternating current worldwide. Other guests have included [[Napoleon III]], [[Theodore Roosevelt]] (at the time of his marriage), [[Rudyard Kipling]] and [[Agatha Christie]] (her book ''At Bertram's Hotel'' is based on Brown's). [[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.|Oliver Wendell Holmes]] in ''Our Hundred Days in Europe'' records staying at Mackellar's Hotel, 17 Dover Street, where "we found ourselves comfortably lodged and well cared for during the whole time we were in London". [[Frédéric Chopin]] took lodgings in Dover Street in 1848 and performed a number of piano recitals in London and undertook piano lessons. In the 1920s many notable photographers were based in Dover Street including [[Paul Tanqueray]], [[Hugh Cecil]] and [[Alexander Bassano]].{{cite web |url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp08077/yvonne-gregory|title=Yvonne Gregory|publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]]|accessdate=20 April 2013}} [[Marcus Adams (photographer)|Marcus Adams]], [[Yvonne Gregory]] and [[Bertram Park]], the "Three Photographers", were based at 43 Dover Street.{{cite web |url=http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp04999/marcus-adams?role=art|title=Marcus Adams |publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]]|accessdate=20 April 2013}} [[Green Park tube station|Green Park Underground station]] was originally known as Dover Street station. The original [[Leslie Green]]-designed building was located in Dover Street, but, following refurbishment in the 1930s to install escalators, the entrance was moved to Piccadilly and the station was renamed. {{cite web | author = Williams, Hywel | date = 7 January 2004 | title = Renamed Stations | work = London Underground History [website] | url = http://underground-history.co.uk/renames.php | accessdate = 26 July 2007 }} ==Clubs== The street is historically and currently the location of a number of well-known London clubs, although the oldest and most fashionable London clubs are located in [[St James's]] and [[Pall Mall, London|Pall Mall]]: * The [[Albemarle Club]], originally in Albemarle Street nearby, was relocated to 37 Dover Street before its closure. * The [[Arts Club]], founded by [[Charles Dickens]] and others in 1863, originally in [[Hanover Square, London|Hanover Square]], has been located at 40 Dover Street since 1893. [[James McNeill Whistler|Whistler]]'s decision to sue [[John Ruskin]] was made on the premises. The Arts Club premises are currently used for meetings of the [[Eccentric Club]]. * The Bath Club, where [[Mark Twain]] breakfasted.{{cite web | author = [[Albert Bigelow Paine]] | year = 1917 | title = Chapter CCLVII, a True English Welcome | work = Mark Twain: a Biography [etext.library.adelaide.edu.au] | url = http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/t/twain/mark/paine/chapter257.html | accessdate = 26 July 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070626165344/http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/t/twain/mark/paine/chapter257.html | archivedate = 26 June 2007 | df = dmy-all }} * The Capisce Club, 1 Dover Street, was formerly a [[nightclub]] and restaurant. * [[Mahiki]], 1 Dover Street, is a [[nightclub]] and bar, with a [[Polynesian culture|Polynesian]] and tiki theme, predominantly specialising in rum. Often frequented by celebrities and royalty, including [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]]. * [https://womanandhersphere.com/category/rooms-of-their-own-womens-clubs/ Empress Club], 35 Dover Street, Towards the end of the 19th century, the idea of a London club solely for women, was put forward by one of Queen Victoria’s Ladies-in-Waiting, With the help of other Ladies at Court, and indeed with the blessing of the Queen herself, the idea went ahead, and on 24 May 1897 the Empress Club opened – founded the “Ladies of England” and in commemoration of her Majesty’s Golden Jubilee. The Club’s foundation marked a new era in the history of Ladies’ Clubs. Unconnected with any political movement it soon became powerful Social Institution. Headed by the Duchess of Leeds, the Vice-Presidents and Committee included a Princess and several Countesses. The original clubhouse was at 32 Dover Street, such was the rush to join that within 12 months a new site had to be found on which to erect a building worthy of the large and influential membership which represented nearly every known family of distinction. The site found was at No. 35, almost next door, and by 1901 the Empress Club was installed in a most impressive and palatial building with another entrance in Berkley Street. It boasted12 Reception Rooms, handsomely decorated, and one hundred bedrooms for which the lowest charge was 4/- a night- and this included Lights, Boots, Bath and attendance. Coal fires, it is true, were 1/6 extra but Ladies’ Maids could be accommodated for 7/6 per day! Members wishing to interview servants at the Club had to give two clear days’ notice to the Secretary and then conduct the interview before 12 noon. Ladies could keep their cycles at the Club, but dogs were not allowed and Gentlemen guests only as far as the Dining and drawing Rooms. An orchestra played during afternoon tea (1/-) and smoking was permitted. It also played in the Grand Dining Hall during dinner, after which smoking was again allowed. Luncheon was 2/6 and dinner 3/6! During the great war over £50,000 was raised by members in aid to the Forces, and again £16,000 in World War II. The Club withstood many near misses from bombs and suffered considerable damage from fire in 1941 After the war the Club never quite recovered its former glory and some years later it was sold. Most of the building was turned into offices and the Grand Dining Hall became a Night Club. In 1961 this was acquired by the Caprice - A l’Ecu de France group, where it became the Empress Restaurant. The property is currently occupied by Christian Louboutin. And a fictional one: * The [[Drones Club]], the gentlemen's club of many of [[P. G. Wodehouse]]'s novels, was located on Dover Street, off Piccadilly. ==Galleries== Art galleries in the street include: * The Alexia Goethe Gallery, 5–7 Dover Street. * The CCA Galleries, 8 Dover Street — originally Christies Contemporary Art and now an independent company publishing prints. * The Gallery at 32 Dover Street (now part of [[Wolf & Badger]]). * Richard Green, 39 Dover Street. * The [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] (ICA) was initially in Dover Street, but relocated to [[The Mall (London)|The Mall]] in 1968. * The Wapping Project Bankside, 37 Dover St, in the same building as [[Mallett Antiques]].{{cite web|url = http://www.bjp-online.com/2014/09/wapping-project-bankside-re-opens-in-mayfair-with-new-exhibition/ | date = 17 September 2014 | accessdate = 23 October 2015 | first = Gemma | last = Padley | magazine = [[British Journal of Photography]] | title = Wapping Project Bankside re-opens in Mayfair}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{commons category|Dover Street, London}} * {{dmoz|/Regional/Europe/United_Kingdom/England/London/Westminster/}} * [http://www.londontown.com/LondonStreets/dover_street_bc0.html LondonTown.com information] [[Category:Mayfair]] [[Category:Streets in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in London|*Dover Street]] [[Category:Art gallery districts]]

page.title: English words first attested in Chaucer

revision.text:
'''English words first attested in Chaucer''', or '''special manuscript words of Chaucer''', are a set of about two thousand English words that [[Geoffrey Chaucer]] is credited as being the first use found today in existing [[manuscripts]].Cannon, p. 129Cannon, pp. 231–233{{cite web |url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/vivian.c/Words/Chaucersnewwords.htm |title=Chaucer’s words |author=Vivian Cook |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2010-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410033512/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/vivian.c/Words/Chaucersnewwords.htm |archivedate=2011-04-10 |df= }} This does not necessarily mean that he was the person to introduce these words into English, but that the earliest extant uses of these words are found in Chaucerian manuscripts.Cannon, pp. 226–230Phelan, pp. 61–70 Many of the words were already in everyday speech in 14th-century England (especially London).Baugh, pp. 193–94Fisher, pp. 7–8 The claim is that these words are found for the first time in written manuscripts where he introduced them in one of his extensive works from 1374 to 1400 as the first author to use these particular words. Many of Chaucer's special manuscript words from the 14th century are used today:
''[[:wikt:absence|absent]], [[:wikt:accident|accident]], [[:wikt:add|add]], [[:wikt:agree|agree]], [[:wikt:bagpipe|bagpipe]], [[:wikt:border|border]], [[:wikt:box|box]], [[:wikt:cinnamon|cinnamon]], [[:wikt:desk|desk]], [[:wikt:digestion|digestion]], [[:wikt:dishonest|dishonest]], [[:wikt:examination|examination]], [[:wikt:finally|finally]], [[:wikt:flute|flute]], [[:wikt:funeral|funeral]], [[:wikt:galaxy|galaxy]], [[:wikt:horizon|horizon]], [[:wikt:infect|infect]], [[:wikt:ingot|ingot]], [[:wikt:latitude|latitude]], [[:wikt:laxative|laxative]], [[:wikt:miscarry|miscarry]], [[:wikt:nod|nod]], [[:wikt:obscure|obscure]], [[:wikt:observe|observe]], [[:wikt:outrageous|outrageous]], [[:wikt:perpendicular|perpendicular]], [[:wikt:Persian|Persian]], [[:wikt:princess|princess]], [[:wikt:resolve|resolve]], [[:wikt:rumour|rumour]], [[:wikt:scissors|scissors]], [[:wikt:session|session]], [[:wikt:snort|snort]], [[:wikt:superstitious|superstitious]], [[:wikt:theatre|theatre]], [[:wikt:trench|trench]], [[:wikt:universe|universe]], [[:wikt:utility|utility]], [[:wikt:vacation|vacation]], [[Valentine's Day#Chaucer's love birds|Valentine]], [[:wikt:veal|veal]], [[:wikt:village|village]], [[:wikt:vulgar|vulgar]], [[:wikt:wallet|wallet]], and [[:wikt:wildness|wildness]].'' {{TOC right|limit=3}} == Etymology == Christopher Cannon, in ''The Making of Chaucer's English'', gives a complete detailed work on the [[etymology]] of Chaucer's special manuscript words and references the [[Middle English Dictionary]] (''MED'') definitions and etymology of each of these words.Cannon, 224-460 He points out that the ''MED'' does not give details on the etymology of many of Chaucer's derived words, including many compounds, some participial [[adjective]]s, and most [[gerunds]]. Cannon also points out that, while the [[Oxford English Dictionary]] lists Chaucer as the ''first cited author'' of these words, it also is mostly silent on the etymologies of these particular derived words.Simpson, Weiner, et al, ''The Oxford English Dictionary''. According to the Library of Congress for those that have academic library subscribing to the OED, here are the steps you can use to find such a list of words: * Once you are in the OED Online, select "Simple Search" found at the bottom of the screen. * Enter the word Chaucer in the box on the upper left of the screen where it says Search for * For the next box below labeled "in," use the pull-down arrow and click on "first cited author." * Most Universities and Colleges and many large public libraries have OED Online where the reference librarian can give you a listing. * The listing output shows Chaucer's works where he is cited as the first cited author of these words and the year the work was published. Cannon furnishes a complete list of Chaucer's special manuscript words with their etymology. Historian Albert Baugh points out that some of Chaucer's [[aureate]] words came from Latin or French origin.Baugh, pp. 186 Some of Chaucer's aureate words like ''[[:wikt:laureate|laureate]], [[:wikt:mediation|mediation]],'' and ''[[:wikt:oriental|oriental]]'' eventually became a part of everyday English. Baugh points out that the innovations of word development into common speech and everyday usage, such as these Chaucer words, is of considerable interest in the history of style.Baugh, p. 186 == List == Below is a complete list of the 1977 Chaucer's special manuscript words that are first found in the existing manuscripts below as listed in the Oxford English Dictionary as being the ''first cited author.'' Some now have different spellings and others are given the "root" word definition. Some of these words are now dated or obsolete.Cannon, p. 232 These manuscript words first found written in Chaucer's work, from ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' and other of his publications as shown below, were published in the 14th century. ===''The Canterbury Tales''=== ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' is a collection of tales written sometime after 1373, with 'sondry folk' that resemble [[Boccaccio]]'s stories of ''[[The Decameron]]'' of fleeing nobles. ==== General Prologue ==== The ''[[General Prologue]]'' introduces the tellers of the tales, with much wry and subtle social commentary. '' [[:wikt:cater|acate]], [[:wikt:affile|affile]], [[:wikt:alight|alight]], [[:wikt:ambler|ambler]], [[:wikt:army|army]], [[:wikt:arrive|arrive]], [[:wikt:bagpipe|bagpipe]], [[:wikt:begging|begster]], [[:wikt:borax|borax]], [[:wikt:bourdon|bourdon]], [[:wikt:bracer|bracer]], [[:wikt:bream|bream]], [[:wikt:cape|cape]], [[:wikt:ceruse|ceruse]], [[:wikt:chape|chape]], [[:wikt:clasp|clasp]], [[:wikt:cordial|cordial]], [[:wikt:dagger|dagger]], [[:wikt:debt|debtless]], [[:wikt:digestible|digestible]], [[:wikt:dormant|dormant]], [[:wikt:Flanders|Flandrish]], [[:wikt:Footstool|foot-mantle]], [[:wikt:foster|foster]], [[:wikt:gaud|gaud]], [[:wikt:hostelry|hostelry]], [[:wikt:householder|householder]], [[:wikt:in|in]], [[:wikt:jingle|jingle]], [[:wikt:knob|knob]], [[:wikt:licentiate|licentiate]], [[:wikt:line|line]], [[:wikt:luce|luce]], [[:wikt:magic|magic]], [[:wikt:magician|magician]], [[:wikt:Bone marrow|marrowbone]], [[:wikt:mercenary|mercenary]], [[:wikt:miscarry|miscarry]], [[:wikt:moral|moral]], [[:wikt:pardoner|pardoner]], [[:wikt:parvis|parvis]], [[:wikt:patent|patent]], [[:wikt:perse|perse]], [[:wikt:session|session]], [[:wikt:significavit|significavit]], [[:wikt:stew|stew]], [[:wikt:wallet|wallet]], [[:wikt:whistling|whistling]] '' ==== The Knight's Tale ==== ''[[The Knight's Tale]]'' introduces many typical aspects of [[knighthood]] such as [[courtly love]] and moral issues. ''[[:wikt:alan|alan]], [[:wikt:attorney|attourne]], [[:wikt:breastplate|breastplate]], [[:wikt:brother|broid]], [[:wikt:buckle|buckle]], [[:wikt:cereal|cerrial]], [[:wikt:chaas|chaas]], [[:wikt:Circe|Circe]], [[:wikt:citrine|citrine]], [[:wikt:coagulation|clottered]], [[:wikt:collared|collared]], [[:wikt:execute|execute]], [[:wikt:expel|expel]], [[:wikt:explosive material|expulsive]], [[:wikt:femininity|feminie]], [[:wikt:flutterbird|fluttery]], [[:wikt:funeral|funeral]], [[:wikt:gigging|gigge]], [[:wikt:holm|holm]], [[:wikt:howl|howl]], [[:wikt:huntress|huntress]], [[:wikt:intellect|intellect]], [[:wikt:kemp|kemp]], [[:wikt:lacing|lacing]], [[:wikt:laxative|laxative]], [[:wikt:Lucina|Lucina]], [[:wikt:melancholic|melancholic]], [[:wikt:menacing|menacing]], [[:wikt:accident|mishap]], [[:wikt:mortal|mortal]], [[:wikt:mover|mover]], [[:wikt:murmur|murmur]], [[:wikt:murmuring|murmuring]], [[:wikt:muzzle|muzzle]], [[:wikt:naker|naker]], [[:wikt:narcotic|narcotic]], [[:wikt:nymph|nymph]], [[:wikt:obsequy|obsequy]], [[:wikt:obstacle|obstacle]], [[:wikt:opie|opie]], [[:wikt:opposite|opposite]], [[:wikt:oyez|oyez]], [[:wikt:parament|parament]], [[:wikt:party|party]], [[:wikt:perturb|perturb]], [[:wikt:pharmacy|pharmacy]], [[:wikt:plain|plain]], [[:wikt:portraiture|portraiture]], [[:wikt:possibility|possibility]], [[:wikt:princess|princess]], [[:wikt:progression|progression]], [[:wikt:refuge|refuge]], [[:wikt:renting|renting]], [[:wikt:returning|returning]], [[:wikt:save|save]], [[:wikt:saving|saving]], [[:wikt:serie|serie]], [[:wikt:shouting|shouting]], [[:wikt:smiler|smiler]], [[:wikt:strangle|strangle]], [[:wikt:strangling|strangling]], [[:wikt:tester|tester]], [[:wikt:thoroughfare|thoroughfare]], [[:wikt:turret|turret]], [[:wikt:vanishing|vanishing]], [[:wikt:variation|variation]], [[:wikt:vital|vital]], [[:wikt:vomit|vomit]], [[:wikt:whippletree|whippletree]], [[:wikt:winged|winged]]'' ==== The Miller's Tale ==== [[The Miller's Tale]] is told by a drunken miller to "quite" (requite) [[The Knight's Tale]]. The word "quite" here means to make repayment for a service - telling stories. '' [[:wikt:almagest|almagest]], [[:wikt:bragger|bragget]], [[:wikt:chant|chant]], [[:wikt:cinnamon|cinnamon]], [[:wikt:forge|forge]], [[:wikt:haunch|haunch-bone]], [[:wikt:interrogation|interrogation]], [[:wikt:keek|keek]], [[:wikt:kneading|kneading]], [[:wikt:manger|kneading-trough]], [[:wikt:lab|lab]], [[:wikt:lie|mislie]], [[:wikt:out|out]], [[:wikt:pearl|pearl]], [[:wikt:Pilate|Pilate]], [[:wikt:piping|piping]], [[:wikt:shelf|shelf]], [[:wikt:slumber|slumber]], [[:wikt:swive|swive]], [[:wikt:tub|tub]], [[:wikt:very|very]], [[:wikt:vere|vere]], [[:wikt:watchet|watchet]] '' ==== The Reeve's Tale ==== [[The Reeve's Tale]] is about two clerks tricking a miller. This tale is possibly based on Boccaccio's sixth story in ''The Decameron.'' '' [[:wikt:bodkin|bodkin]], [[:wikt:bolt|bolt]], [[:wikt:chime|chime]], [[:wikt:derere|derere]], [[:wikt:easement|easement]], [[:wikt:Grazing|grass time]], [[:wikt:halfway|halfway]], [[:wikt:jossa|jossa]], [[:wikt:messuage|messuage]], [[:wikt:mullock|mullock]], [[:wikt:popper|popper]], [[:wikt:quack|quack]], [[:wikt:sack|sack]], [[:wikt:Sheffield|Sheffield]], [[:wikt:thick and thin|thick and thin]], [[:wikt:varnish|varnish]] '' ==== The Cook's Tale ==== [[File:Wife-of-Bath-ms.jpg|thumb|From the first page of Canterbury Tales: ''''' The Wife of Bath's Tale '''''[http://www.librarius.com/canttran/wftltrfs.htm The Wife of Bath's Prologue]]] [[The Cook's Tale]] is a tale of an apprentice named Perkins who is fond of drinking and dancing. He ultimately is released from his master and moves in with a friend. This friend's wife is a prostitute. The story becomes more 'seedy', continuing the downward trend of the preceding tales. ''[[:wikt:bribe|bribe]], [[:wikt:convertible|convertible]], [[:wikt:galliard|galliard]], [[:wikt:Harry|Harry]], [[:wikt:Hodge|Hodge]],'' ''[[:wikt:look|louke]], [[:wikt:apprenticeship|prenticehood]]'' ==== The Man of Law's Tale ==== [[The Man of Law's Tale]] is a story about a Christian princess named Constance. She is to marry a Syrian Sultan on condition that he convert to Christianity. His mother gets involved and sets her adrift at sea.
